summaries: Lucas Cranach sends a depiction of the Virgin painted by a member of the Cranach workshop who was patronised by the electoral treasurer Hans von Ponickau (1508-1573). He assures that there is visible progress and confirms that he did not assist in any way. Cranach sends three invoices with a total sum of 100 guilders together with the painting. He requests that the money be taken by Master Lorencz Lindeman to Leipzig. Furthermore he informs Ponickau, that he is working successfully on an altarpiece commissioned by the elector.
items.transcription:
[Bl. 10r]
Genad vnd frid in Cristo vnd mein gancz wiliger dinst sey ewer gestrengkait ale zeit zu vor bereit, gestrenger liber her, hie schick ich euch ein Maria mit einem kindlein, ein brust pild, hat ewer maler gemacht, ich hab in gar nichts dar angeholfen, er hats allein gemacht, da secht ir wol, wie er sich pesert [etc.]. Gestrenger liber her, hie schick ich euch drey quitanczen, die machtn gleich 1 hundert f[loren] vnd pit, wolt vorschafen, das sulchs gelt meinem guten freundt, magister Lorencz Lindeman, macht werden, der will mirs gen Leipczig vber antworten, das will ich vmb ewer strengkait wider vor dinen vnd wist, das ich mit ganczem fleis an der tafel mach in die kirchen meines genedigstin herenn [etc.] Dat[um] am [sunabent ? gestrichen] freitag nach s(ankt) Gorgen im [15]45 yar.
E[uer] f[ürstlichen] g[naden] u[ntertäniger] diner Lucas Cranach, maler zu Wittenbergk
[Bl. 10v u. 11r (bilden eine Einheit als Adresse)]
Dem gestrengen vnd erentvesten hernn Hans von Ponickaw kamerer [etc.] meinem liben heren vnd gros forderer [Petschaft u. Archivvermerk: Reg. AA, gestrichen darüber Rr, Pag. 138 A VII Nr. 214]
items.locationAndDate: the Friday after St George's day in the year [15]45
items.signature: Ernestinisches Gesamtarchiv, Reg. Rr S. 1-316, Nr. 937, Bl. 10r v u. 11r
items.comments: From the letter it would appear that Hans von Ponikau suppported an artist who was being trained in the Cranach workshop (see Schade 1974, 440, no. 353).
items.transcribedBy: Heydenreich, Gunnar; Lücke, Dietrich; Lücke, Monika
items.verification: Schuchardt 1851 A, 175 f.; Scheidig 1953, 172, no. 55; Schade 1974, 440, no. 353; Heydenreich 2007, 441, no. 269
items.scans: Scan zu ThHStAW, EGA, Reg. Rr S. 1-316, Nr. 937, Bl. 10r, 10v u. 11r

summaries: Hans Rudolf, the duke's treasurer, recorded the outcome of Duke Johann Friedrich's negotiation with Cranach regarding his outstanding salary. On behalf of the former elector Rudolf gives notification that Cranach will receive outstanding payments from Michaelmas 1546 to Easter 1547 to the sum of 50 guilders. Cranach will renounce his salary for the following year and a half and payment will recommence from the 23rd of July 1550. Cranach is obliged to work for the duke and his sons and to stay close to them.
items.transcription:
[Bl. 12r]
Zuwissen,
das mein gnedigister herr uff meister Lucaßen Cranachs, malers, ansuchenn seiner besoldung halbenn, ime mundlich dißen bescheid durch mich, Hansen Rudolf, hatt lassen geben.
Erstlichen belangende di halbe jharsbesoldung, so ime von Michaelis anno [15]46 bis uff osternn des [15]47d[en] jhars ausstehen solle. Dorumb wolle man sich in registern der renterei ersehenn, unnd do di betzalung nichtt gescheen, sol ime solch[er] halbe jharssold als funftzig guld[en] entrichtt werd[en].
Aber von osternn des [15]47d[en] jhars antzufahenn bis uff den mitwoch nach Marie Magdalene, das ist den 23d[den] des monats julii des vorschinen funftzigist[en] jhars. Weil meister Lucas Kranach hochgedachttem meinem gnedigist[en] herren nichtt gedinett, sundern zu Wittenberg geweßen, sol ime nichts gegeben werd[en]. Wie es dan auch meister Lucas zufriden ist, und di forderung fallen zulassen gewilliget.
Und dieweil gedachter meister Lucas den 23d[en] julii im funftzigist[en] jhar, das ist der mitwoch nach Marie Magdalene, uff hochermelts meins gnedigist[en] herren begerenn zu sein f[ürstlichen] gn[aden] gein Augsburgk komen, unnd widderumb bei s[einer] f[ürstlichen] g[naden] sich zu dinst eingesteltt, so soll von solch[er] zeitt anzurech[nen] ime alle jhar unnd di zeitt seins lebenns ain hundert gulden muntz folgenn und gereicht werd[en]. Als where uff den jungstverschinen drei und zwentzigist[en] tag des monats julii dißes itzttlauffenden ain und funftzigist[en]
[Bl. 12v]
jhars ain jharsold vertagtt und vorfallenn.
Als ist ime solch[er] vertagt[en] und vorfallenen anderthalb jherigenn besoldung halben, und was kunfftiglich weiter fellig wirdett werden, der bescheid gegeben, das er solche felhafftige besoldung bei meinem gnedigist[en] herren sol stehen lassen, der gestaltt, wan s[eine] f[ürstliche] g[naden] durch Gottes des almechtigen hulf irer gefengnus entledigett werden, oder aber s[eine] f[ürstliche] g[naden] meister Lucaßen sonst[en] anhaims erleuben wurden, welchs doch in s[einer] f[ürstlichen] g[naden] willen und gefallen stehen solle, so wollen s[eine] f[ürstliche] g[naden] ime an derselbig[en] freundlichen liben sone ain schrifft geben lassen, die besoldung[en], so sich von obberurt[en] funftzigist[en] jhar, den 23d[en] julii, antzurechenen jherlich vertagtt, zu betzalenn.
Welchen artikel gedachter meister Lucas auch gewilliget. Und wiewhol er mitt angehengtt, wen es uff das zwei und funftzigeste jhar, als den 23 julii keme uf die zeitt ime zwu jharbesoldung zuenttricht[en] geburt[en], das mein gnedigister herr ime diselbig[en] zweihundert gulden und dan di erste ausstendige halbe jhar besoldung, davon oben gemeldett, entrichttenn lassen, di woltte er seinen sonen, zu betzalung etzlich[er] schuld geben.
So hatt ime doch s[eine] f[ürstliche] g[naden] widderumb sag[en] lassen, di ablegung und
[Bl. 13r]
betzalung solch[er] vertagt[en] jharbesoldung wolle s[eine] f[ürstliche] g[naden] nicht seinen kindern, sundern ime thun und volgen lassen, domitt er in seinem altter, wan er zumalen nicht mher vermochte, auch ein bharen pfennig hette. Sintemal er sonst[en] seinen kindern, alle sein gutt gegebenn, dorbei er es auch hatt bleib[en] lassen, und zufrid[en] geweßen.
Dargegen aber und das mein gnedigist[er] herr gewilligett, ime jherlich und uf sein lebenlang sein besoldung volgen zulassen als 1 c fl [100 Gulden] jherlich, hatt sich meister Lucas verpflichtett und bewilliget bei s[einer] f[ürstlichen] g[naden] in irer verhafftung so lang es s[einer] f[ürstlichen] g[naden] gefellig, auch wuhin sein f[ürstliche] g[naden] ziehen, zubleibenn.
Do dan auch sein f[ürstliche] gn[aden] durch gotliche verleihung der gefengnus endledigett, wolle er undter sein f[ürstliche] gn[aden] unnd derselbig[en] sonen meinen gnedigen jungen herren, sich wesendlich nidder thun unnd di zeitt seins lebens iren f[ürstlichen] gn[aden] dinstwertig sein und bleib[en].
Act[um] Augsburgk, den acht[en] tag des monats octobris, anno d[o]m[ini] 15 c [hundert] im 51d[en]. 
			[Unterschrift:]  H[an]s  Rhudolff
[Bl. 13v]
Lucass Maler bestellung belangend 1552
items.locationAndDate: Augsburg, the 8th day of the month of October, anno d[o]m[ini] 15 c in 51
items.signature: Ernestinisches Gesamtarchiv, Reg. Rr S. 1-316, Nr. 937, Bl. 12r, 12v, 13r u. 13v
items.comments: Of interest is also the comment that Cranach had already given his inheritance to his children and had debts to pay.
items.transcribedBy: Heydenreich, Gunnar; Lücke, Dietrich; Lücke, Monika
items.verification: Schuchardt 1851 A, 195-198; Schade 1974, 443, no. 399; Heydenreich 2007, 450, no. 314
items.scans: Scan zu ThHStAW, EGA,  Reg. Rr S. 1-316, Nr. 937, Bl. 12r, 12v, 13r u. 13v

summaries: A certificate of appointment for Lucas Cranach the Elder confirming payment of an annual salary of 100 guilders, summer and winter clothing as well as board. Duke Johann Friedrich secures pre-emption rights to all works by Cranach. Reference is made to the provision from the 8th of October 1551.
items.transcription:
[Bl. 14r]
Vonn Gotts gnaden, wir Johanns Fridrich der elter, hertzog zw Sachssenn unnd gebornner churfurst [etc.], lanndtgraff inn Duringenn unnd marggraff zu Meyssenn, thun kundt unnd bekennenn vor unns unnd die hochgebornne furstenn, unnsere freundtliche liebe sohne, gegenn mennigklichenn, 
Nachdeme weylanndt die auch hochgebornne furstenn, herr Fridrich unnd herr Johanns gebrudere, hertzogenn zu Sachssenn unnd des Heiligen Romischenn Reichs ertzmarschahl unnd churfurst[en], unnsere freundtliche liebe vetter unnd gnediger herr vater selige gedechtnus, unnserm lieben getrewenn Lucaß Cranach als irer lieb unnd gnade bestaltem diener unnd mahler jherlich ein hundert gulden dinnstgeldt unnd die winter unnd  sommer hoffkleydung uff sein leib reichenn lassenn, ihme auch solche besoldung die zeit seins lebenns jerlichenn zugebenn gewilliget, welche wir gedachtem meister Lucaßenn nach seiner lieb unnd gnad[en] absterbenn jerlich zuenntrichtenn, inngleichnus gnediglich bewilliget unnd bey unnser regierung bis uff Michaelis des sechs unnd viertzigstenn jars volgenn habenn lassenn, welcher besoldung er auch alle jar vorgnuget unnd bezalet wordenn ist bis uff ein einzige halbe jar besoldung, die ihme vonn wegenn unnsers verloffenenn kriegs seinem bericht nach vonn obberurter zeit Michaelis im sechs unnd viertzigstenn bis osternn des siebenn unnd viertzigstenn jars nicht enntrichtet worden sein solle. Derwegenn wir aber inn unnser renntherei erkundung nehmenn lassenn unnd alsdann  der bezalung halbenn uns auch gnediglich erzeigenn wollenn, wie dann solchs alles weiter inn einer besondern vorzeichnus am datum Augspurgk, den achtenn tagk des monats octobris, im ein unnd funffzigistenn jar vorschienen datirt zubefindenn, davon meister Lucassenn ein abschrifft zugestaltt wordenn ist. Alß habenn wir gedachtem meister Lucassen, dieweil er weder vonn unnserm vedtern noch herrnn vatern seligenn keine vorschreibung daruber gehabt unnd sich uff unnser gnediges begernn vonn Wittembergk aus einem unnterthenigenn mitleiden unnd damit uns inn unser lanngwirigenn verhafftung die zeit nicht zu lanngweiligk, zu unns gegenn Augspurgk den 23ten tagk july inn vorflossenem funffzigistenn jar verfugtt unnd bey unns bis zu unnser von Gott aus kayserlicher mayestadt, unnsers aller gnedigstenn herrn, milde und guthe verliehenenn erledigung verharret, anngezeigte ein hundert guldenn gnaden unnd dinnst geldes vonn berurtem dreyunndzwenntzigstenn tag des monats julii annzurechenenn, zusambt der winter unnd sommer hoffkleydung voriger unnsers vettern unnd herrnn vater seliger auch unnser bewilligung nach die zeit seins lebenns vorschrieben und bewilliget.
Vorschreibenn ihme anngezeigte ein hundert guldenn zusambt den zweyenn hoffkleydungenn, auch die cost zu hoff hiemit und inn crafft ditz brieffs die zeit seins lebenns.
Dargegenn soll er unns unnd unnsernn sohnenn auch die zeit seins lebens unnd sonnst niemanndts mit dinstenn verwanndt, auch schuldigk sein, wie er sich dann darzu unnterthenigklich erbothen, bey uns unnd unnsernn freundtlichenn liebenn sohnenn die zeit seins lebens zubleibenn unnd sich vonn unns nicht zubegebenn, wie es auch mit bezalung unnd enntrichtung der besoldung so albereit bis zwey jar lanng uff diese vorschreibung sich vertagt gehaltenn soll werdenn. Solchs bringet obgemelt vorzeichnus der abrede clerlich mit. Derselbigenn nach wollenn wir unns, wann er des geldes notturfftigk sein wirdet, zuerzeigenn wissenn,
Welchs alles meister Lucas mit unntertheniger danncksagung anngenohmenn, gelobt unnd zugesagt, auch daruber seinn reversbrieff gebenn hat. Dem allenn, was ihne betreffenn unnd diese bestellung gegenn unns unnd unnsernn sohnenn verbindenn thut, nachzukommenn unnd sich sonstenn zu haltenn, wie einem getrewenn diener gegen seinem herrn zuthun geburet unnd wol annstehet.
Unnd bevehlenn demnach hierauff unnsern rennthmeister, renthschreibern unnd hoffgewanndts außteilern gedachtem meister Lucassenn anngezeigte ein hundert guldenn muntz unnd die sommer unnd winter hoffkleidung zureichenn unnd zugebenn. Des soll ein jeder inn rechnung enntnohmenn werdenn unnd geschiet darann unnser meinung,
Zu urkundt mit unnserm zuruckauffgedrucktem secret besiegelt unnd gebenn zu Weymar, mitwoch nach omnium sanctorum, anno domini xvclii [02.11.1552]
[linke Randbemerkung bei Beschreibung der Aufgaben Cranachs:] Insonderheit aber vnsere arbeitt auch mitt allem vleis fertig[en] und umb solch unser gnaden geld und gn[ä]dig[en] undterhalttung willen, solche seine arbeitt, was er uns malen etwas nehme, dan einen frembd[en] zulassen. 
[Bl. 14v]
Lucas Cranachs bestallung uff lebenlang, dargeg[en] ihm gleichfals 100 f[loren], winter und sommerkleidung jeerlich zugeben auß gnaden sind verschriebe[n] worde[n] 1552.
[Inventarnummer: Reg. RR, fol. 121 lit. C.6 Nr. 87]

It can be assumed that Cranach received a more recent copy, including the additions (in the margin). See also the discussion regarding the privilege in Neugebauer/Lang 2015, p. 11-17.

summaries: Johann Friedrich, Duke of Saxony instructs his treasurer to pay Lucas Cranach, who had arrived in Augsburg on the 23rd of July 1550, 100 guilders of his annual salary. Cranach had evidently asked for this payment. In addition to the 35 thalers he had already received he was to be paid a further 100 guilders.
items.transcription:
[Bl. 15r]
Vonn gots gnaden Johans Fridrich der elder, hertzog zu Sachsen und geborner churfurst, landgrave in Duringen und marggrave zu Meissen [etc.]
Liber ratt und getreuer. Wir wollen dir nitt bergen, das wir unserm maler maister Lucasen Kranach in unser verhafftung, wie er im verschinen funftzigisten jhare uf mitwoch nach Maria Magdalene [23.07.1550] zu uns gegen Augsburgk kommen, jherlich ain hundertt gulden, wie ime die von unserm vedtern und herren vater seliger gedechttnus gereichtt, von bestimbter zeitt antzurech[nen] zugeben bewilligett.
Nach deme er uns den berichtett, das er zu entrichttung etzlicher schulden ain hundert gulden bedurfftig. So begeren wir, du wollest ime gegen geburlicher bekenttnus uf angetzaigte besoldung und weit[er] abrechnung etzliche arbeitt, die er uns nach inhaltt inverwartter vertzeichnung gemachtt, dorauf er albereitt funf und dreissig thaler empfangen, die gebetene ain hundertt gulden in muntz uf rechnunge reichen und geben.
Daran geschiett unsere meynunge. Datum Weimar dornstags, den 27d[en] monatstag octobris, anno domini xv c im liid[en] [27.10.1552]
[Bl. 15v]
Unserm rendmaister, rath unnd libenn getreuenn, Jacoben vonn Koseritz
Der Rennthmeister sol dem maler, meister Lucaß[en] Cranach, ein hundert gulden uf seine besoldung unnd weiter aberechnung gebenn, unnd zustellen, 1552.
items.locationAndDate: Weimar, Thursday the 27th day in the month of October, anno domini xv c in lii

summaries: Lucas Cranach acknowledges the receipt of 50 guilders handed over to him by representatives of the council of Neustadt an der Orla for the panel (altarpiece).
items.transcription: Ich, Lucas Crannach zu Wittenberck, mit dieser meiner hantgeschrift beken, das mir dye geschickten des rats zu der Neustat an der Orlaw von wegen irs gotshaus funffczig f[loren] reinisch zu Leipczig im herbstmarck anno im alften [1511] iar vor auf die arwet, die sie mir einer tafel halben an gedingt, entricht haben.
items.locationAndDate: Leipczig, during the autumn market anno eleven [1511]
items.signature: Ernestinisches Gesamtarchiv, Reg. Rr S. 1-316, Nr. 937, Bl. 16r
items.comments:
In 2013 there was conference dedicated to the Neustadt Altarpiece. Alexander Krünes studied the available sources in the church archive Neustadt/Orla within this context (see Krünes 2015, 301-312). The material was also published earlier in a more extensive form (Krünes 2013, 445-476).
The original invoice was supposedly lost during the war and Scheidig doubts the authenticity of the copy. Schade refers to catalogue entries from an auction at Stargardt, Marburg 28-29.05.1963, No. 563 and 24-25.11.1964, No. 570. The original had the inventory number ThHStAW, Reg. B. 31904, Bl. 48a. The origin of the copy now in the file is not documented. However the handwriting can be attributed to Cranach.
items.transcribedBy: Heydenreich, Gunnar; Lücke, Dietrich; Lücke, Monika
items.verification: Scheidig 1953, 159, no. 13; Hoffmann 1954, 15-16; Schade 1974, 405, no. 82; Hintzenstern/Dressler 1986, 58; Heydenreich 2007, 412, no. 45; Krünes 2014, 446; Krünes 2015, 303-304

items.comments: Quatemberfasten (ember day)1534 is the week after the first Sunday in Lent [Invocavit] or the 23rd to the 28th of February. On the reverse the payment date is recorded as the second Sunday in Lent [Reminiscere], which would have been the 1st of March.

summaries: Lucas Cranach pays 7.5 groschens as special tax for the construction of the large bastion, a fortification for the city of Wittenberg. For the first time he acquires a small quantity of building material (250 bricks).
items.transcription:
[Bl. 83r] 
Innham der stewer zcum bawe der grosßen pasteyn ahn whall gebawet 
7,5 g[roschen] Lucas moler

[Bl. 93v]
Innham vor zcigell des sechsten offen, ist außgefurth sonnabent nach Martini, hat gehalten 22 tawssent dreyhundert, nemlichen 12.900 mawersteynn, 7.800 flachsteynn vnd 1.600 sentsteynn
mawersteynn 7,5 g[roschen] Lucas moler 250
items.locationAndDate: 1510, the Saturday after St Martin's day
items.signature: Städtische Sammlungen Wittenberg, Ratsarchiv, Kämmereirechnung 1510, Bl. 83r und 93v
items.comments:
Lucas Cranach was for the first time held liable by the city of Wittenberg to pay a special tax of 7.5 groschens for a house in the market quarter. He pays the same sum as Gores Seiler, Marcus Otto, the widow of Peter Hutter and Jacuff/Jacob Cleinschmidt. Cranach was not recorded in either the summer or winter tax list from 1510. Else Salomon was assessed in this position and she was replaced from 1512 by the town judge Caspar Teuschel.  The finance department's account book from 1511 is missing.
See Schade 1974, 405, no. 77, here misinterpreted as 8 groschens.
items.verification: Schade 1974, 405, no. 77; Lücke 1998, 34, no. 1; Hennen 2011 (Universität und Stadt), 145, Hennen 2015 (Cranach 3D), 315.
items.scans: Scan KR 1510, Bl. 83r und 93v

summaries: On Walpurgis 1512 Lucas Cranach pays the communal taxes (summer and winter levy of 27 and 50 groschens respectively) for two houses on the Market Square and fees (6 groschens and 10 pfennigs) for the first time. He receives a tax reduction of 6 groschens and 10 pfennigs. He pays 20 groschens for each house for the tax levied for the construction of the fortification around the city, and is given a tax exemption of 20 groschens for one house. A further fee of 10 groschens per house is due to support Schlieben (a town east of Wittenberg) - Cranach is given a tax-exemption here of 10 groschen. He buys a large quantity of building material (65 wagons of lime, 17,500 bricks).

items.locationAndDate: 1512, Walpurgis, Michaelmas
items.comments:
For the first time Lucas Cranach is recorded in the tax list as the owner of two properties. According to recent research these objects are two houses on the Market Square that can be identified today as Markt 4 and 5 (see Hennen 2015 B, p. 315). However, the fact that the finance department's account books for 1511 were lost must also be considered. See also Straube 1985, among others p. 153, Fn. 42 with some erroneous details, which for many years resulted in incorrect conclusions. 
A 'Meister Lucas' appears on the list of revenues for building material. The tax lists were checked to establish whether another 'Meister Lucas' was held liable in 1512. Besides Lucas Cranach a Lucas Petzch, who evidently died (on Michaelmas Petzch paid the outstanding tax) and a gardener called Lucas Kühne paid communal taxes.  A 'Meister Lucas' with extensive building projects can only refer to Lucas Cranach. In the following years the name 'Meister Lucas' is no longer used. 
In Wittenberg the currency denomination of 'Schock' is already calculated in 'neue Schock' = 60 pieces,  here 60 groschens per Schock.
items.verification: Schade 1974, 406, no. 102 (hier zu 1512/13); Straube 1985, u.a. 153 Anm. 53; Lücke 1998, 34f., no. 2 und 43, no. 17 sowie 35, no. 3

summaries:
In 1513, as in the previous year, Cranach pays communal taxes and fees for two properties. In addition to the summer and winter taxes for the two houses on the market square he also pays for two gardens (5 and 4 groschens respectively).  For the first time he is given a tax reduction of 17 groschens on one property. Back taxes demanded by the council  are recorded for him with the sums of 50 groschens (for summer and winter taxes respectively), 6 groschens and 10 pfennigs (rates), 20 groschens tax for the bastion and 15 groschens to support Schlieben, in total 2 schock, 21 groschens and 10 pfennigs. Back payments amounting to 2 schock, 16 groschens and 10 pfennigs due by Cranach for an 'old house' were waived by the council. 
The building material purchased by Cranach only constituted 1000 bricks. For the first time he paid the sum of 4.

items.locationAndDate: 1513, Walpurgis, Michaelmas
items.comments:
For the first time Cranach is given a tax exemption of 17 groschens for one of his properties, just as the previous owner Caspar Teuschel (for five years), because Cranach does not yet own this house five years.  
Back taxes amounting to 2 Schock, 16 groschens and 10 pfennigs due by Cranach for an 'old house' are waived by the council. This can only refer to Cranach's second house.
Schade 1974, 407, no. 103 without separating the individual amounts

summaries: In 1514 Lucas Cranach pays communal taxes and fees for two properties each at 27 and 50 groschens summer and winter taxes, as well as for two gardens. For his house that was formerly owned by Caspar Teuschel he is given a tax reduction for a second year of 17 groschens for the summer and winter taxes, as well as for rates (6 groschens 10 pfennigs) and withholding tax for construction work on the municipal stables (20 groschens). In addition Cranach obtains 25 wagons of chalk from the municipal oven.

summaries: Lucas Cranach pays the municipal taxes and fees for two properties, receives for the third year a tax reduction on one house. In addition he pays rates for two 'Rademarcksche' Hufen (farmland outside Wittenberg) and livestock tax. Cranach purchases building material (6 wagons of chalk and 300 bricks) and pays 15 groschens wine tax.

summaries: Lucas Cranach pays the municipal tax and fees for two properties, two gardens and two 'Rademarksche Hufen' (farmland outside Wittenberg) as in the previous years. He receives a final  tax reduction (17 groschens). New here is the bridge toll for crossing the Elbe at a fare of 2 pfennigs per crossing. Cranach is charged 14 fares.

items.locationAndDate: 1520, Walpurgis, Michaelmas etc.
items.comments:
Sheet 39v: Lucas Cranach acquired the apothecary, on the 6th of December 1520 he received the electoral privilege and had to employ an apothecary as he did not have the required qualifications for the job. Here for the first time a 'Peter Apotecker' was listed along with tax exemptions for the new construction of a house.
Sheet 101v: An infection with common bunt is here dated to Thursday, Pantaleonis. This is probably a mistake. Pantaleonis¿ day occurs annually on the 28th of July and in 1520 this fell on a Saturday. June the 28th was a Thursday in that year.
items.scans: Scan Kämmereirechnung 1520, Bl. 8r, 18r, 19v, 20r, 32r, 39v, 41v, 43r, 43v, 52r, 55r, 63v, 83r, 92v, 101v, 103r, 125r

summaries: Lucas Cranach continues to pay the communal tax for the property in Schloßstr. 1. In addition he pays for a property (summer and winter taxes of 20 groschens respectively) and a stall (summer and winter taxes of 8 groschens respectively) in the Neue Gasse. For both Cranach receives a tax exemption for a final year. In this year Cranach purchases a large quantity of building material from the municipal brickyard: 106 wagons of chalk, 7000 bricks, 7300 roof tiles and 700 slanted roof tiles (Gleyfstein). The two gardens and the the two Rade[Rothe]marksche Hufen (farmland outside Wittenberg) remain in his possession. The wine tax for the retail sales of wine amounts to 2 schocks and 41 groschens.

items.locationAndDate: 1521/1522, Walpurgis, Michaelmas etc.
items.comments:
The wine tax, levied for the retail sales of wine is at 2 schocks and 41 groschens only a fraction of the amount from the previous year. 
Gleyfstein: for a description of tile forms see Stephan 2011, 146-163, here in particular 156f.with descriptions and illustrations of tile forms. 
According to Hennen 2015, 321f. the new properties can be identified as Neustraße 8 (8 groschens) and on the corner of Neustraße/Mittelstraße (summer and winter taxes of 20 groschens respectively). 
Sheet 125r/v: St John the Evangelist¿s day is the 27th of December, which fell on a Friday in 1521. The document was however dated to the Friday after St John¿s day, which would have been the 3rd of January 1522.
items.verification: Lücke 1998, 33 f.; Hennen 2011, 141 f.; vgl. auch Stephan 2011, 146-163, hier bes. 156f., Hennen 2015 (Cranach 3D), 321 f

summaries: In this year Lucas Cranach was again elected treasurer by the council of Wittenberg. Duties associated with the office incude payments to the council members. In addition to the properties in Schloßstr. 1 and the other two houses (each assessed at 8 or 20 groschens repectively for summer and winter taxes) an additional property is assessed at 27 groschens for summer and winter taxes respectively. Taxes continue to be paid for both gardens and Rade[Rothe]marksche Hufen  (farmland outside Wittenberg). Cranach purchases further building material, comprising of 100 wagons of chalk, 8000 bricks and 1200 tiles in the municipal brickyard.

items.locationAndDate: 1522, Walpurgis, Michaelmas etc.
items.comments:
In 1522 Lucas Cranach purchases a house on the market square in Wittenberg. It is assessed at 27 groschens for summer and winter taxes respectively. It is one of the houses that Cranach paid tax on in 1512. He purchased it from the town judge Caspar Teuschel. In 1518 it was owned by Valentin Mellerstadt, the heir of Schloßstr. 1 (see Lücke 1998, 29). According to Hennen 2015, pp. 315-317 it can be identified as Markt 5. See also Lücke 2017, 296-298.
Florsteyne = floor tile, see Stephan 2011, p. 158f. with illustrations.
items.verification: Lücke 1998, 16-19, 29; Hennen 2011 (Universität und Stadt), 141-145; Stephan 2011, 146-163; Hennen 2015 (Cranach 3D), 315-318; Lücke 2017 ("Das ernestinische Wittenberg". Anmerkungen), 293-306

summaries: Lucas Cranach pays communal taxes for his house in Schloßstr. 1, another house and a stall, two gardens and two Rade[Rothe]marksche Hufen (farmland outside Wittenberg). In addition he pays 1.5 groschens and 1 groschen 6 pfennigs for summer and winter cattle tax, and wine tax amounting to 6 schocks, 2 groschens and 3 pfennigs (the town's total revenue is 10 schocks, 47 groschens and 9 pfennigs). Cranach purchases 500 roof tiles from the municipal brickyard.

items.verification: Lücke 1998, 16?19, 29; Hennen 2011 (Universität und Stadt), 141-145; Hennen 2015 (Cranach 3D), 315-318; Lücke 2017 ("Das ernestinische Wittenberg". Anmerkungen), 293-306

summaries:
In this year Lucas Cranach is elected treasurer by the council of Wittenberg for the first time. Duties associated with this office include payments to the council members. 
His property in the town remains limited to Schloßstr. 1 for which he pays communal taxes. The same applies to the gardens and the Rade[Rothe]markschen Hufen (farmland outside Wittenberg). Cranach pays summer tax of 15 groschens for a small house.   
New here is the wine tax for retail sales of wine at 8 schocks 44 groschens. Apart from 1 schock 35 groschens this amount is almost the entire wine tax (10 schocks, 19 groschens) paid by citizens for retail sales of wine. Cranach starts a large-scale tavern business, which he acquired with the new house.

items.comments: The house for which Cranach paid a summer tax of 15 groschens was only in his possession for a very short period. See here a contract from the 1st of January 1520 (Lücke 1998, 38, no. 11) and Hennen 2015 (Cranach 3D), 321 identified as Bürgermeisterstraße 12.

summaries: Lucas Cranach pays communal taxes for his house in Schloßstr. 1, another house and a stall, two gardens and two Rade[Rothe]marksche Hufen (farmland outside Wittenberg). Cattle tax is not charged. In addition he pays wine tax amounting to 9 schocks, 44 groschens and 9 pfennigs (the town's total revenue is 11 schocks, 29 groschens and 6 pfennigs).

Sheet. 85v: The entry concerning Melchior Lotter the Younger was included, because he was for a time employed by Lucas Cranach.

summaries: Lucas Cranach pays communal taxes for his house in Schloßstr. 1, another house and a stall, two gardens and two Rade[Rothe]marksche Hufen (farmland outside Wittenberg). Also due are the cattle tax amounting to one groschen and three pfennigs, the rates for property owners and the wine tax for retail sales at 5 schocks, 14 groschens and 6 pfennigs. For the first time Cranach was liable for tax (Schatzgeld) for brewing beer and brewing rights on his properties. This had already been settled in 1525, but the first tax demand was in 1526. The taxes were settled for six years. The 'Schatzgeld' was also to be paid for retail sales of wine - for Cranach this amounts to one schock groschen.
Cranach complains and the council waives part of this tax. He purchases building material from the municipal brickyard, paying 60 groschens for 2000 bricks and 60 groschens for 2000 roof tiles.

items.locationAndDate: 1526, Walpurgis, Michaelmas etc.
items.comments:
Sheet 88v: The entry concerning Melchior Lotter was included, because he was for a time employed by Lucas Cranach.
Sheet 141r: Tax for brewing beer is introduced. This tax reform was settled by the mayor Dr. Christian Beyer and introduced the following year in 1526 by the mayor Hans Hondorff. Each citizen was permitted  7 brews.  For each brew 5 groschens tax was due. In addition a tax of 10 groschens was charged for houses with brewing rights. 
One brew constituted 6 barrels each containing 393 liters. In 1526 Cranach pays 50 groschens for 10 brews. This means that 60 barrels of beer (about 23,580 liters) were brewed. See Lücke 2017 A, 267f.
Regarding the properties owned by Cranach see bibliographical entries for DE_StSWR_KR-1522 and DE_StSWR_KR-1523.

summaries:
In 1528 Lucas Cranach is again a member of the council under the mayor Hans Hondorf and receives the usual payment. 
In this year Cranach pays the summer taxes for four properties and the winter taxes for five properties as well as the other municipal rates. In addition to the properties in Schlossstrasse, am Markt and in Neue Gasse he has a stall (2 groschens and 7 pfennigs winter tax). Besides the two Rade[Rothe]markschen Hufen (farmland outside Wittenberg), the two gardens and 'einer Breite' (plot of land) he pays tax of 1 groschen and 9 pfennigs for another garden. The garden belonged to Mattes Segermacher. Cattle tax of 1 groschen and 3 pfennigs is also due. 
Cranach purchases building material in the municipal brickyard (10000 bricks)
The wine tax is 3 schocks 25 groschens and 6 pfennigs, the beer tax is 30 groschens.
The income for 'Heerfahrtssteuer' (war tax) is also listed for 1528. Cranach pays 23 schocks, 25 groschens and 7 pfennigs from his assets, which amounted to 1405 schocks, 36 groschens.

summaries:
Lucas Cranach pays 27 groschens municipal tax for the house in the market square, 1 schock groschen for the property in Schloßstr. 1.8 groschens for a stall, 20 groschens for the house in Neue Gasse and 7 groschens, 6 pfennigs and 2 groschens, 7 pfennigs respectively for two other stalls. 
Besides  these he pays 5 groschens and 3 groschens respectively for two gardens as well as 3 groschens (formerly the property of Hans von G[J]henin) and 1 groschen and 9 pfennigs (formerly belonging to Mattes Segemacher) for a further two gardens. In addition he pays 12 groschens for an orchard. For two Rade[Rothe]marksche Hufen (farmland outside Wittenberg) the tax and interest is due.
Withholding tax is due on the six above mentioned properties to the sum of 1 schock and 15 groschens and for the garden of a tavern.

Cranach purchases 100 roof tiles for 3 groschens from the municipal brickyard. 
Tax for retail sales of wine amounts to 5 schocks, 16 groschens and 6 pfennigs, and he pays 30 groschens for the retail sales of six brews of beer.

items.locationAndDate: 1529, Walpurgis, Michaelmas etc.

summaries:
In this year Lucas Cranach continues to pay summer and winter taxes for 6 properties as well as the relevant rates.  Furthermore he pays for four gardens, an orchard and the two Rad[Rothe]markschen Hufe (farmland outside Wittenberg). The cattle tax amounts to 1 groschen and 6 pfennigs. 
Cranach purchases 6 wagons of chalk for 15 groschen, 2000 bricks for 1 schock groschen and 500 roof tiles for 15 groschens. 
This year he does not pay wine tax, but beer tax amounts to 25 groschens for 5 brews. 
Noted under 'general expenses' is the fact that the council owes Cranach for planks, workpieces and timber and this is to be offset against the tax payment (2 schock groschen).

items.locationAndDate: 1530, Walpurgis, Michaelmas etc.
items.comments: In 1530 Cranach did not pay tax for retail sales of wine.

summaries:
Cranach pays tax and municipal rates for five properties, three gardens, a 'Breite' (plot of land) as well as two Rade[Rote]marksche Hufen (farmland outside Wittenberg). He purchases building material at the municipal brickyard: 800 Florsteine (obsidian?) for 24 groschens, 200 roof tiles for 6 groschens and 1200 bricks for 36 groschens. 
Cranach pays 6 schocks, 51 groschens for wine tax and as in the previous year 30 groschens brewing tax. 
Under the council's general expenses a transfer of 7 groschens and 6 pfennigs to the pharmacy is listed for material required by the town scribe to make ink. The same applies to the sum of 3 groschens and 9 pfennigs for 1.25 pounds of sealing wax as well as 36 groschens and 6 pfennigs for spices and mixed spices for two council meetings.

In addition Cranach receives 1 schock, 8 groschens and 10 pfennigs for a delivery of timber to the new butcher's stalls and material for the expansion of the town hall. Older debts owed by the council to Cranach are paid as had been done in previous years. Cranach received 2 schocks, 37 groschens and one pfennig in 1528, 2 schocks in 1530, 2 schocks in 1531 and 4 schocks in 1532. The remainder amounting to 2 schocks, 51 groschens and 2 pfennigs was to be offset in 1533.

Darnach im 32t[en] jhare haben yhme alle drey rethe noch vhier schogk abetzurechen befolhen vnd zcugesagt. Darauff ist obangetzaigt schogk 8 g[roschen] 10 d[enare] vorrechendt. Alßo bleybt yhme der rath schuldigk 2 ß [Schock] 51 g[roschen] 2 d[enare], die selben yhme im 33t[en] jhare abegetzogen werd[en]
items.locationAndDate: 1532, Walpurgis, Michaelmas etc.
items.comments: The expenses owed by the council to the pharmacy [fol. 22r.] were listed here, because Cranach was the owner of the pharmacy.

summaries:
In 1534 Cranach is again a council member and town treasurer and receives the usual payment. He pays tax and municipal rates for five properties, three gardens and a 'Breite' (plot of land) as well as the two Rade[Rote]marksche Hufen (farmland outside Wittenberg). 
In this year Cranach rents the council tavern for 70 gilders, because of building work on the town hall. He is permitted to sell sweet and other wine as well as beer not brewed by him. He is not charged any additional wine tax. 
The tax for brewing beer sinks from five to three groschens per brew. Cranach pays 18 groschens for six brews.

Cranach delivers provisions, wine (3 schocks and 19 groschens) and spices like ginger, safran etc. to the council for the sum of 54 groschens and 2 pfennigs. Further deliveries were official gifts, like Einbeck beer and Kötzschenbroda wine for a reception with Duke Heinrich of Saxony known as 'the Pious'.

summaries:
In this year Lucas Cranach pays the municipal taxes and rates for three houses, two stalls, three gardens and two Rade[Rothe]marcksche Hufen (farmland outside Wittenberg).
Wine tax is again paid for the retail sales of wine (6 schocks, 56 groschens). Cranach no longer rents the council tavern. 12 groschens are due for 4 brews of beer. 
In the expenses for the municipal buildings Cranach is paid 3 schocks and 30 groschens for painting and gilding the hands of the clock on the church tower.

items.comments: Fol. 151r: council expenses 'for the collation' refers exclusively to council members. Lucas Cranach, who at present is not in office, only receives the smaller sum of 8 groschens, as the large council dinner to celebrate the change of the board members was cancelled because of the plague.

summaries:
Lucas Cranach pays municipal taxes and rates for three houses, two stalls, three gardens and two Rade[Rothe]marcksche Hufen (farmland outside Wittenberg).
The wine tax is paid on retail sales (6 schocks, 31.5 groschens). 18 groschens is due for six brews of beer.

items.locationAndDate: 1536, Walpurgis, Michaelmas etc. until the Purification of the Virgin 1537
items.comments: Fol. 142r: Council expenses 'for the collation' refer exclusively to council members. Lucas Cranach is not a present a member and therefore receives only a small sum of 8 groschens.

summaries: In 1528 war tax (or so-called 'Türkensteuer') was levied on real estate. The citizens were to provide the information for assessment themselves. The properties (houses, farmland and garden) are recorded in the appendix of the finance department's account book. Two months wages for 200 soldiers were to be paid from the taxes. For every schock silver groschen one silver groschen in tax was to be paid.
items.comments:
In 1528 the war tax (Türkensteuer) was levied as tax on property. The summary, including tax payments, is recorded from fol.138 in part 1 of the finance department¿s account book from 1528 (see also levied `Türkensteuer¿ from 19.03.1542). 
The register is arranged according to boroughs:  the 'Coswigviertel' [fol. 2r-12v], the 'Marktviertel' [13r-24v], the 'Judenstraßenviertel' [25r-36v] and the 'Elsterviertel' [37r-50v].  This is followed by a list of property outside the town: beyond the Elbtor  [fol. 51r), the suburbs and gardens beyond the Coswiger Tor (fol. 52r-55r), the suburbs and gardens beyond the Elstertor (fol. 55v-58r) as well as others with gardens for which tax was paid to the council (fol. 59v-60v).
The tax register is by comparison a valuable source for the social topographical study of Wittenberg (see bibliography).
items.scans: Scan Kämmereirechnung 1528/2, Bl. 1r-60v

summaries:
Lucas Cranach becomes mayor of Wittenberg for the first time. He receives the payment and tax exemption he is entitled to in this position. His wife is also mentioned here - she and her servants receive 25 groschens as a tip for the preparation of the council's meal. The wedding of one of Cranach's daughters is mentioned in association with the sum of 19 groschens 4 pfennigs for two Stübchen (measurement: 1 Stübchen = 2 jugs) of wine from the Rhein and Franconian regions given to the foreign guests. 
Cranach also pays the municipal tax and rates for three houses, two stalls, and two farmyards outside the town walls. 
Wine tax is levied on retail sales (6 schocks 47 groschens). 18 groschens are due for six brews of beer.

Wine tax is levied on retail sales (7 schocks 35.5 groschens). 15 groschens are due for 5 brewed beers.

items.locationAndDate: 1539, Walpurgis, Michaelmas etc./ 1540, until the Purification of the Virgin in the fortieth year
items.comments: In 1539 Lucas Cranach was not originally a member of the governing council of Wittenberg. However he received the privileged tax relief of an acting council member. The same applies to Benedict Pauli. Both became members of the council during the year, replacing Claus Heffner, who had originally been confirmed.

summaries:
In this year Lucas Cranach is once again acting mayor. He pays municipal tax and rates on three houses, two stalls, one orchard (Breite) and two farmyards outside the city walls.
Wine tax is levied as usual on retail sales (4 schocks, 53 groschens). 18 groschens are due for 6 brews of beer.
Cranach's wife and her servants receive 25 groschens as a tip for preparing a banquet for the council. She receives 10 groschens at the fair held on St Gall's day. She is paid 1 schock and 10.5 groschens for a barrel of beer.

The council office paid Cranach's pharmacist the following: 1 schock, 32 groschens and 7 pfennigs for spices and other pharmaceutical products, 29 groschens and 2 pfennigs for ingredients for ink and sealing wax, 51 groschens and 4 pfennigs for the medical treatment of Hanns Jobst, the market master, who had been bitten in the fist by a 'mad' person, then became ill and subsequently died, as well as 52 groschens and 9 pfennigs for medicine for numerous watchmen and officials.

items.locationAndDate: 1540, Walpurgis, Michaelmas etc.
items.comments:
A further reference to Cranach's wife [fol. 143r] can be added to the few facts already known. On the 16.10.1540 she receives 10 groschens at the fair. See in this context thoughts on her date of death at the end of 1540 (Schade 1974m 439, No. 328).
Fol. 34r: here the mistake 'Walpurgis' is corrected on the next page.
The relatively extensive list of wares from Cranach's pharmacy is striking.

summaries: In this year Lucas Cranach is again an acting council member, pays the municipal tax and rates for three houses, one stall, three gardens, an orchard (Breite) and two farmyards outside the city walls. One of his stalls is transferred to Dr. Pommer (Johannes Bugenhagen).

items.locationAndDate: 1541, Walpurgis, Michaelmas etc.
items.comments:
Cranach still pays the board (Tischgeld) for the stall (assessed at 8 groschens in 1540) listed on fol. 59v, although Dr. Johann Bugenhagen (Pommer) was already paying the taxes for the stall in 1541. 
The wine tax is not listed this year. The treasury account book is only 102 pages thick and is less than half the size of previous years. 
The whole volume was available to Karl Eduard Förstemann for his research on the Cranach family and he cites the following from the treasury account book, 1541: 4 schocks, 42 groschen Doctor Brucken [the chancellor Gregor Pontanus] und Lucassen Cranach uf ihrer Tochter [Barbara Brück und sohn [Lucas Cranach the Younger] Wirtschaft [wedding] verehrt, Nemlichen 3 schock 34 Groschen an 2 eimer 19 Quart Rheinischen Wein, und ein Schock 8 groschen vor 1 Zentner Karpfen, Sonnabend nach Valentini. [19.02.1541]
(Einiges zu Lucas Cranachs Erben und über seine Nachkommen, NMGHAF 2 (1836, p. 651, see Scheidig-Kartei C. 608/609)

summaries:
In 1547 Cranach only pays for one house (his residence, Schloßstr. 1) and a stall - his son-in-law Caspar Pfreundt has taken over the second house. Further payments made are related to two orchards (Breiten), a farmyard, two gardens and the farmyards outside the town. 
Listed in the council's expenditure account are payments of 8 groschens to the pharmacy, 2 schocks, 37 groschens and 1 pfennig to Cranach for a delivery of timber to the town hall building site, that was long overdue. 
A wine tax amounting to 1 schock and 55 groschens was levied, and beer tax of 27 groschens.

summaries:
Lucas Cranach the Younger is again an acting member of the council. 
In 1549 Cranach the Elder pays for his residence (Schloßstr. 1) and a stall. Further payments made are related to two orchards (Breiten), a farmyard, two gardens and the farmyards outside the town. 
Wine tax amounting to 2 schocks and 10 groschens was levied, and 12 groschens beer tax.
Cranach buys building material: 24 wagons (1 schock, 36 groschens), 400 bricks and 300 roofing tiles.

items.locationAndDate: 1549, Walpurgis, Michaelmas etc.
items.comments:
This year Lucas Cranach the Younger is a member of the Wittenberg Council. he was a council member for the firat time in 1546 (see Lücke 2017, 226). 
The title of the entry on fol. 122v is on fol. 120r.
items.scans: Scan Kämmereirechnung 1549, Bl. 2r, 6r, 54v, 101r, 102v, 120r/122v, 125v, 129r, 130r, 140v, 141v, 179r

summaries:
Cranach pays the municipal tax for his residence (2 schocks for Schloßstr. 1), a stall (5 groschens and 2 pfennigs), two orchards (Breiten, 24 and 10 groschens), the farmyards outside the town walls (8 groschens) plus board and mortgage rates. Cattle tax amounts to 3 groschens. Wine tax was levied at 19 guilders and 5 groschens, beer tax was 15 groschens. 
The bill of the treasurer's office dated 19.12.1550 includes a sum of 377 guilders and 2 pfennigs owed to Cranach. This was balanced against Cranach's debt, which amounted to 66 guilders, 5 groschens and 8 pfennigs.
Moreover Mattes Mewen was paid 10 guilders and 6 pfennigs - as payment of Cranach's outstanding debt. The council owed the remaining amount of 300 guilders to Cranach.
